League]]) <br>[[Sony Sendai F.C.]] ([[Japan Football League|JFL]]) | seating_capacity = 19,694 | dimensions = 139 x 79 m }} '''Yurtec Stadium Sendai''' (ユアテックスタジアム仙台) is a [[football (soccer)|football]] stadium in the Nanakita Park, Izumi-ku, [[Sendai|Sendai City]], [[Miyagi Prefecture]], [[Japan]]. It was built in 1997 and is home to the [[J. League]] club [[Vegalta Sendai]] and the [[Japan Football League]] club [[Sony Sendai F.C.]]. The stadium was specifically designed for football, and the stands are arranged close to the pitch. For games where the spectator capacity is insufficient, nearby [[Miyagi Stadium]] is occasionally used as a substitute. ==History== The naming rights for the stadium were sold beginning on March 1, 2006 until February 28, 2009. In that period, the stadium is officially known as {{Nihongo|''Yurtec STADIUM SENDAI''|ユアテックスタジアム仙台|Yuatekku Sutajiamu Sendai}}. In 2009, the turf were replaced, and Vegalta played the first half of the season at Miyagi Stadium.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.kahoku.co.jp/spe/spe106/news_spe/news20080408_001.htm|title=仙台―広島戦宮スタが会場|publisher=河北新報|date=2008-04-08|language=Japanese|accessdate=2008-04-08}} {{Dead link|date=October 2010|bot=H3llBot}}</ref> The stadium was damaged after the [[2011 Tōhoku earthquake and tsunami]].<ref>{{cite news |title=Japan cancels all March games in top soccer league |author= |url=http://news.yahoo.com/s/ap/20110314/ap_on_sp_so_ne/soc_earthquake_soccer_suspension;_ylt=Ak8A6VqFUi6zDeHDN9RZTroLMxIF;_ylu=X3oDMTMxYXFyMHVnBGFzc2V0A2FwLzIwMTEwMzE0L3NvY19lYXJ0aHF1YWtlX3NvY2Nlcl9zdXNwZW5zaW9uBGNwb3MDMwRwb3MDNQRzZWMDeW5fdG9wX3N0b3J5BHNsawNqYXBhbmNhbmNlbHM- |newspaper=Yahoo! Sports |date=2011-03-14|accessdate=2011-03-14}}</ref> == International Matches == ===Football=== [[Italy national football team|Italy]] used the stadium as their base for training camp during the [[Football World Cup 2002|2002 World Cup]], and cast images of the team members footprints are on display outside the stadium. The '''Sendai Cup''' (An international youth football tournament) has been held annually since 2003. Italy, France [[Brazil national football team|Brazil]], and [[Croatia national football team|Croatia]] have participated, along with the hosts, [[Japan national football team|Japan]]. Exhibition matches between Vegalta Sendai and [[A.C. ChievoVerona]] and [[S.S. Lazio]] have been played at Sendai Stadium as well. The match with Chievo in 2003 was the final club game for [[Oliver Bierhoff]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.soccerway.com/news/2003/june/4/japan-stars-tune-up-for-internationals/?print=yes|title=Japan stars tune up for internationals|publisher=Soccerway|date=2004-06-03|accessdate=2008-04-08}}</ref> ===Rugby=== On June 16, 2007 the stadium was the venue for [[Japan national rugby union team|Japan]] vs. [[Samoa national rugby union team|Samoa]] in the [[2007 IRB Pacific Nations Cup]]. It was the first time an international rugby game had been played in the [[Tōhoku region]]. On June 15, 2008 Japan defeated [[Tonga national rugby union team|Tonga]] 35-13 at the stadium in the [[2008 IRB Pacific Nations Cup]]. == Access == * [[Nanboku Line (Sendai)|Nanboku Line]]: 8 minutes walk from [[Izumi-Chūō Station (Miyagi)|Izumi-Chūō Station]]. ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== {{commons category}} * [http://www.wldcup.com/Asia/stadia/sendai.html Pictures of Sendai Stadium] (Much information on this site is out of date) * [http://www.worldstadiums.com/stadium_pictures/asia/japan/tohoku/sendai_stadium.shtml WorldStadiums.com entry] {{Vegalta Sendai}} {{J.
